Available online 20 July 2025 Article Engineering coordination microenvironments of polypyridine Ni catalysts embedded in covalent organic frameworks for efficient CO2 photoreduction Ya-Hui Li Yu Chen Jin-Yu Guo Rui Wang Shu-Na Zhao * Gang Li * Shuang-Quan Zang * Henan Key Laboratory of Crystalline Molecular Functional Materials, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China Henan Key Laboratory of Crystalline Molecular Functional Materials College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou Henan 450001 China Henan Key Laboratory of Crystalline Molecular Functional Materials, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China * Corresponding author The coordination engineering of catalytic centers emerges as a pivotal strategy for precise electronic configuration modulation in photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Herein, the electronic structure of active sites in polypyridine nickel catalysts is well modified through strategic ligand variation (bipyridine, terpyridine (TPY), 2,6-di(1-pyrazolyl)pyridine) and anion coordination (NO3 –, Cl–, and CH3COO–), achieving enhanced CO2 performance. Crucially, covalent immobilization of these molecular catalysts within the COF-OH framework not only preserves their precisely defined and structurally adaptable characteristics but also demonstrates synergistic enhancement of CO2 adsorption capacity and charge transfer kinetics, as verified by CO2 adsorption isothermal analysis and ultrafast time-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy. Remarkably, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) catalyst exhibits a CO2-to-CO reduction activity of 9006.0 μmol·g–1·h–1 with 95.9% selectivity, superior to its counterpart catalysts, directly validating the mechanistic significance of precisely tailored coordination microenvironments around Ni active sites. Mechanistic studies through in situ XAFS, in situ ATR-SEIRAS and theoretical calculations reveal that this performance improvement over COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) is attributed to the reduced reaction energy barrier of *COOH generation. This work pioneers a coordination shell engineering paradigm for rational design of molecularly defined catalytic architectures. Graphical Abstract This study optimized the electronic structure of polypyridine nickel catalysts that embedded on the skeleton of COF-OH by modifying the surrounding ligands (BPY, TPY, BPP) and coordinating anions (NO3 –, Cl–, and CH3COO–). These modifications can enhance charge transfer and reduce *COOH formation barriers, resulting in outstanding performance for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Keywords Coordination number Anion regulation Covalent organic framework Polypyridine nickel catalyst Photocatalytic CO2 reduction 1 Introduction In response to the challenges posed by global climate change and energy scarcity, the conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals using solar energy has emerged as a pivotal research area. This approach aims to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions while providing sustainable alternatives for carbon-based feedstocks [ 1–6 ]. In recent years, metal polypyridine complexes have been extensively employed as molecular catalysts for photocatalytic CO2 reduction [ 7,8 ]. These metal polypyridine complexes typically possess multi-π electron-conjugated structure, which facilitates their electron transfer and storage capabilities [ 9 ]. Furthermore, metal polypyridine complexes consistently feature well-defined and tunable central metal ions or the surrounding ligands. This characteristic facilitates the optimization of adsorption strength for reaction intermediates during CO2 reduction, thereby enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity. Metal complexes featuring bipyridine (BPY) [ 10 ], terpyridine (TPY) [ 11 ], and quaterpyridine (QPY) [ 12 ] ligands have emerged as promising candidates for CO2 reduction, exhibiting ideal photocatalytic activity and selectivity. Nevertheless, the practical applications of molecular catalysts are often restricted by challenges related to catalyst recovery, which may result in increased costs, potential catalyst loss, and environmental risks. Loading molecular catalysts onto suitable supports [ 13–18 ] to integrate their advantages of molecular catalysts into the resulting heterogeneous catalysts is a promising strategy to enhance the performance of photocatalysts for CO2 reduction. Wang et al. [ 16 ] repored a UiO-type MOF bearing a bipyridine linker, which can be further functionalized with single Co(II) sites for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Remarkably, the photocatalytic performance of UiO-Co-Nx (x = 2, 3, and 4) is influenced by the N coordination number surrounding the Co sites, as it not only regulates the charge-transfer dynamics but also affects the electronic density of single Co sites [ 16 ]. Furthermore, the simultaneous precise modulation of first and second coordination shell on bipyridine nickel catalysts UiO-Ni-X-Y (X = S, O; Y = H, Cl, and CF3) embedded within UiO-67 skeleton was achieved by modifying the coordinated group (e.g. –SH or –OH) and functional groups (e.g. –H, –Cl, or –CF3) of the ligands. Both the first and second coordination spheres significantly influence photocatalytic performance, underscoring the necessity of precisely regulating coordination microenvironment of active metal sites in photocatalysis [ 19 ]. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [ 20–27 ], characterized by well-defined porosity, tunable microstructure, highly crystalline π-conjugated structure, and high water stability, have emerged as another ideal support materials to integrate multiple functional components for photocatalytic CO2 reduction [ 28–32 ]. The pre-installed specific metal active sites in the COF network, such as BPY [ 33 ], porphyrin [ 34 ], salen [ 35 ], etc., are a general strategy to functionalize COFs for photocatalytic applications [ 36–42 ]. Zhang et al. [ 43 ] designed three benzoxazole(BBO)-based COF photocatalysts incorporating Co ions with distinct coordination geometries: Co-N-O2, Co-N-O3, and Co-N2-O2. Among them, BBO-COFBPY-Co exhibits the best photocatalytic activity with CO yield of 10552.15 μmol·g–1·h–1 and selectivity of 91%, underscoring the critical role of the coordination environment in COF-based photocatalytic systems. Recently, Dai et al. [ 44 ] fabricated single-site Co(II) catalysts with different coordinated anions (F–, Cl–, CH3COO–, and NO3 –) supported on a bipyridine-based COF, and demonstrated the coordinated anions on the metal sites can influence the photocatalytic performance of CO2 reduction. However, introducing active sites through the pre-installed approach makes it difficult to regulate their ligand types, resulting in challenges in obtaining a well-defined structure [ 45,46 ]. The functionalized organic skeleton of COFs offers an ideal platform for anchoring catalytic centers with tunable structures through covalent linkages using a post-synthetic modification (PSM) strategy. Lu et al. [ 47 ] confined a MnMo6 polyoxometalate within the regular nanopores of a COF via a Schiff base reaction, achieving outstanding photocatalytic CO2-to-CO performance in a gas-solid reaction system. A cyclopentadiene Rh(III) unit was successfully grafted onto COF skeleton via amidation reaction, resulting in excellent performance for the [ 4 + 2 ] annulation reaction [ 48 ]. With this in mind, the PSM strategy was developed in this work to create high-efficiency photocatalysts. Specifically, we synthesized three polypyridine nickel catalysts based COFs materials (COF-O-Ni) by covalently linking polypyridine nickel catalysts (Br-BPYNi, Cl-TPYNi, and I-BPPNi) with the hydroxyl groups of COF-OH via the Williamson reaction (Scheme 1 ). This approach not only preserves the well-defined and highly tunable structural advantages of polypyridine nickel catalysts, but also extends visible light absorption, enhances charge separation, and facilitates recyclability. Notably, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibited significantly improved performance for photocatalytic CO2 reduction, achieving an efficiency of 9006.0 μmol·g–1·h–1 and selectivity of 95.9%. This surpasses the results of COF-O-TPYNi(Cl–) (4588.4 μmol·g–1·h–1, 87.3%) and COF-O-TPYNi(CH3COO–) (3591.8 μmol·g–1·h–1, 94.1%), indicating the significant influence of coordinating anions on the catalytic performance of photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Furthermore, these values are 2.4-fold and 5.2-fold higher than those of COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) and COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) under the same conditions, which can be attributed to the different coordination environments of the metal sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All reagents were purchased from commercial sources without further purification. 2,4,6-tris(4-aminophenyl)-1,3,5- triazine (TAPT, 98%, Yanshen Technology), 2,5- dihydroxybenzene-1,4-dicarboxaldehyde (2,3-DHTA, 97%, Alfa Aesar), 5-bromo-2,2’-bipyridine (Br-BPY, 98%, Energy Chemical), 4’-chloro-2,2’:6’,2’’-terpyridine (Cl-TPY, 98%, Energy Chemical), 4-iodo-2,6-di(1H-pyrazol-1-yl)pyridine (I-BPP, 98%, Alfa Aesa), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98%, innochem), tris(2,2’-bipyridyl) ruthenium(II) chloride hexahydrate (98%, Energy Chemical, Ru(bpy)3Cl2·6H2O), 1,2-dichlorobenzene (DCB, 99%, extra dry, with molecular sieves, Energyseal), 1-butanol (99%, extra dry, with molecular sieves, N2 gas (99.99 vol%, Xinxiang Yuxin Gas Manufacturing Co., Ltd) and CO2 gas (99.999 vol%, Xinxiang Yuxin Gas Manufacturing Co., Ltd) were used in the present work. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Br-BPYNi, Cl-TPYNi, and I-BPPNi The Br-BPY (1.0 mmol) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1.2 mmol) were added into a 25 mL vessel with 3 mL MeCN. The solution was heated to 65 °C and maintained for ca. 4 h under argon to give a pale green solid. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was isolated by centrifugation and washed with MeCN to remove unreacted metal salts and ligands. These findings are consistent with previously reported results [ 50 ]. The presence of a characteristic absorption peak in the FT-IR spectra at 1662 cm–1 provides direct evidence for the formation of imine bonds (C=N), further confirming the successful synthesis of the COF-OH material (Fig. 1(c)). Additionally, COF-OH possesses a high BET surface area of 1556 m2·g–1 and two distinct pore windows measuring 1.5 and 2.6 nm, respectively, which are sufficiently large for loading polypyridine nickel catalysts (Figs. 1(d) and S1). Furthermore, COF-OH demonstrates excellent thermal stability, with a decomposition temperature of up to 430 °C (Fig. S2). Collectively, these results support the conclusion that the robust OH-containing COF is promising platform for grafting polypyridine nickel catalysts. The PXRD patterns of COF-OH incorporated with polypyridine nickel catalysts (denoted as COF-O-Ni shown in Fig. 1(a)) were well matched with those of the bulk COF-OH, providing clear confirmation of the preservation of the COF-OH structure (Fig. 1(b)). The solid-state 13C NMR spectra of COF-O-Ni samples exhibit all the characteristic peaks obserbed in COF-OH, further corroborating the structure integrity of the COF-OH platform (Fig. S3). FT-IR spectra revealed that the C=N stretching vibrations in COF-O-Ni samples remained intact after the PSM, indicating that the covalent linkages within the framework were unaffected during the PSM process (Fig. 1(c)). Additionally, a stretching vibration associated with (C–O–C) ether bonds at 1258 cm–1 was observed after PSM, suggesting successful covalent grafting of polypyridine nickel catalysts onto the channel walls of COF-OH [ 50 ]. The BET surface areas of COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –), COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –), and COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) were calculated to be 990, 846, and 1309 m2·g–1, respectively (Figs. 1(d) and S1). The decrease in BET surface areas for the COF-O-Ni samples compared to pristine COF-OH can be attributed to the occupied volume of the Ni molecular catalyst and/or slight lattice distortion, as evidenced in the PXRD patterns. Furthermore, no visible changes in the morphology of COF-O-Ni samples were observed after modification, further confirming the structural stability of the COF-OH platform. Additionally, HR-TEM and AC-HAADF-STEM images of COF-O-Ni samples confirm the atomic dispersion of Ni atoms over the COF-OH platform (Figs. 2(a)–(c) , Figs. S4–S6). No signal of halogen atoms was detected in energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis of COF-O-Ni samples, further confirming the covalent grafting of polypyridine nickel catalysts (Fig. S7). ICP-OES analysis reveals that the Ni content in COF-O-Ni samples is 5.87 wt%, 7.32 wt%, and 8.74 wt%, respectively. Additionally, XPS measurements were conducted to investigate the surface chemical composition and electronic structure of COF-O-Ni samples (Figs. S8–S12). The characteristic signals of Cl 2p, Br 3d, and I 3d are nearly undetectable in COF-O-Ni samples compared to the mixture of COF-OH and polypyridine nickel catalysts before the reaction (Fig. S10). Meanwhile, the high-resolution O 1s spectra show an addition peak at ~531.24 eV, indicating the formation of C–O–C. These results further verify the successful loading of different polypyridine nickel catalysts into pristine COF-OH through a covalent connection (Fig. S11). As shown in Fig. S12, for COF-TPYNi(NO3 –), the high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p exhibit predominant peaks at 856.13 eV (Ni 2p 3/2) and 873.54 eV (Ni 2p 1/2), accompanied by satellite signals, suggesting that the valence state of the Ni atom is +2. The Ni 2p 3/2 binding energies follow the trend: COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) (855.87 eV) < COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) (856.43 eV) < COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) (857.05 eV). This indicates that TPYNi exhibits stronger coordination with the hydroxyl group in COF-OH compared to BPYNi and BPPNi, as COF-OH donates electrons to Ni(II), reducing the electron deficiency [ 51 ]. The electronic and local coordination structures of the Ni units in COF-O-Ni samples were further analyzed at the atomic level using X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS). As shown in the Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra (Fig. 2(d)), the absorption edge positions of COF-O-Ni samples are similar to that of NiO, suggesting the bivalent nature of the Ni atoms in all three COF-O-Ni samples. In the Fourier transform k2-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) curves (Fig. 2(e)), all COF-O-Ni samples exhibit a prominent peak at ~1.53 Å, which lies between the Ni–N (1.47 Å) in Ni phthalocyanine (NiPc) and the Ni–O (1.63 Å) in NiO scattering path, indicating the coexistence of Ni–N and Ni–O coordination in the first coordination shell. Furthermore, no Ni–Ni peaks at ~2.16 Å were detected, confirming the atomic dispersion of the Ni atoms in the COF-O-Ni samples. The wavelet transform (WT) analysis of the COF-O-Ni samples, which exhibits high resolution in both k and R space, further corroborates these findings. Additionally, EXAFS fitting results verified that each Ni atom is coordinated with approximately three N and three O atoms in all COF-O-Ni samples, consistent with the polypyridine nickel catalysts (Figs. 2(f)–(i), Figs. S13, S14, and Table S1). Collectively, these results demonstrate the successful covalent grafting of Ni moieties onto the backbones of COF-OH while preserving their original structures. 3.2 Photocatalytic performance The photocatalytic performance of the as-prepared catalysts for CO2RR was evaluated using a mixed solvent of MeCN/H2O (4:1) with a photosensitizer ([Ru(bpy)3]Cl2·6H2O) and a sacrificial reagent (1,3-dimethyl-2-phenyl-2,3-dihydro- 1H-benzimidazole, BIH) under visible-light irradiation (≥ 420 nm). Notably, a comprehensive investigation was conducted to examine the impact of both the first and secondary coordination shells on the photocatalytic CO2RR performance. Among all the photocatalysts, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) achieved the highest CO production rate of 9006.0 μmol·g–1·h–1, with an outstanding CO/H2 selectivity of 95.9% after 2 h of light irradiation (Fig. 3(a) ). When the TPY ligand is replaced with BPY or BPP ligands, the CO production activity of COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) or COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) significantly decreases to 3734.8 and 1716.5 μmol·g–1·h–1, respectively, with CO selectivities of 91.0% and 86.1%, respectively. These results confirm that the second coordination sphere, which influences the electronic structure of the metal center through long-range electron delocalization, leads to distinctly different catalytic activities. Additionally, coordinating anions such as nitrates, chloride ions, and acetates also impact the first or secondary coordination shells of the active center, thereby affecting the catalytic performance. In terms of CO2-CO conversion, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibits the highest CO production rate of 9006.0 μmol·g–1·h–1 with 95.9% selectivity towards CO, followed by other COF-O-TPYNi catalysts with different anionic ligands in the order of COF-O-TPYNi(Cl–) > (4588.4 μmol·g–1·h–1, 87.3%) > COF-O-TPYNi(CH3COO–) (3591.8 μmol·g–1·h–1, 94.1%). The above results demonstrate the crucial roles of synthesis routes and coordinating anions in regulating the photocatalytic activity of COF-O-Ni catalysts. The measured CO production rate of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) is comparable to and even better than some recently reported nickel-based photocatalysts (Fig. 3(b) and Table S2). These findings demonstrate the promising potential for practical applications in CO2 conversion through precise tailoring of the coordination environment of catalytic sites within COFs. Moreover, the AQY of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) was systematically quantified across multiple wavelengths, peaking at 0.20% under 450 nm illumination (Fig. S15). In addition, isotope-labeled 13CO2RR experiments were conducted to investigate the carbon source of CO products. As shown in Fig. S16, the peak at m/z = 29 in the mass spectrum confirms that the generated 13CO originates from 13CO2, demonstrating that the CO is derived from CO2 rather than from potential contaminants. Negligible amounts of CO were detected in the absence of light irradiation, BIH, and [Ru(bpy)3]2+, highlighting the crucial roles of these factors in photocatalytic CO2 conversion. As shown in Fig. 3(c), when CO2 was replaced with N2 in the photocatalytic system, only trace amounts of H2 and no CO were detected, indicating that CO is derived from CO2 [ 49 ]. Additionally, the poor photocatalytic CO2RR activity and product selectivity of pristine COF-OH reveal the essential role of TPYNi sites as the real active sites. The TPYNi exhibits limited photocatalytic performance, producing 749.8 μmol·g–1·h–1 CO and 149.7 μmol·g–1·h–1 H2, indicating the significant role of COF-OH in facilitating electron transfer. Moreover, the physical mixture of COF-OH and TPYNi yields 791.4 μmol·g–1·h–1 CO and 118.5 μmol·g–1·h–1 H2, which is much lower than that of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) under the same conditions. This suggests that the strong covalent connection between COF-OH and TPYNi effectively enhances charge separation and transfer efficiency between the two components. The good photocatalytic stability of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) was verified through five CO2 reduction cycle tests with only slight deterioration (Fig. 3(d)). The PXRD patterns demonstrated that the crystallinity and structural integrity of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) were retained after recycling tests (Fig. S17). Moreover, the presence of C=N and C–O–C in the FT-IR and XPS spectra of the post-reaction sample further confirms that both the COF-OH skeleton and molecular covalent linkage remains intact after photocatalysis (Figs. S18 and S19). The high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p indicated that COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) maintained the valence of nickel after recycling tests (Fig. S19(d)). Correspondingly, HR-TEM images of the post-reaction sample revealed that the morphology of COF-OH was well preserved, with no discernible growth or agglomeration of Ni NPs (Fig. S20). These results collectively indicate the excellent stability of the COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) catalyst during the photocatalytic CO2RR. 3.3 Mechanism of photocatalytic CO2 reduction To elucidate the underlying factors for excellent photocatalytic performance, photoelectrochemical properties of the as-prepared catalysts were performed. As shown in Fig. 3(e), chopped photocurrent responses were measured by turning lights on and off at the same time interval. Both COF-OH and TPYNi exhibit poor photocurrent density due to the fast recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. After covalently grafting polypyridine nickel catalysts onto COF-OH, a noticeable increase in photocurrent intensity was observed. Notably, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) demonstrated the largest and most stable photocurrent response among the COF-O-Ni samples, revealing its superior interface charge transfer and separation ability. Furthermore, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibited the lowest charge transfer resistance in EIS spectra (Fig. 3(f)), further indicating its exceptional charge transfer kinetics. Solid-state UV-vis DRS spectrum shows that covalently grafting polypyridine nickel catalysts onto COF-OH resulted in a slight red-shift of the absorption edge (Fig. S21). This observation suggests that the incorporation of polypyridine nickel catalysts as active centers enhances light-harvesting properties and increases electron delocalization in COF-OH [ 52 ]. The optical bandgaps of COF-O-Ni samples were determined as 1.79, 1.71, and 1.86 eV by Tauc plots, respectively (Fig. S22). Correspondingly, the conductive and valence band positions of TPYNi and COF-O-Ni samples were calculated through a combination of Mott-Schottky results and their optical bandgaps (Figs. S23 and S24). The results indicate that the CB position of all the COF-O-Ni samples is situated above the redox potential of CO2/CO (–0.52 V vs. NHE) (Fig. S25), rendering them thermodynamically suitable for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 [ 53 ]. In-situ XAFS experiments were conducted to dynamically monitor the oxidation state of Ni sites (Fig. 4(a) ). The Ni K-edge XANES spectra were collected under three conditions: Ar atmosphere, CO2 atmosphere, and CO2 atmosphere with light illumination. Upon switching from an Ar atmosphere to a CO2 atmosphere, a slight upward shift of 0.123 eV in energy at the Ni K-edge of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) was observed. This shift can be attributed to spontaneous electron transfer from the Ni active center to the C 2p orbital of adsorbed CO2. Furhtermore, the Ni K-edge of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibited a slight downward shift of 0.156 eV under light illumination, with energy values even lower than those in the Ar atmosphere. This shift suggests the formation of low-valent Ni species during photocatalytic CO2 reduction, which can be attributed to the transfer of photogenerated electrons from the COF-OH framework to the Ni active sites. Therefore, in-situ XAFS results reveal that the Ni sites within the TPY group are the true active sites for CO2 reduction . Furthermore, CO2 sorption studies on COF-OH and COF-O-Ni samples were performed at 0 and 25 °C, respectively (Figs. 4(b) and S26). All the COF-O-Ni samples exhibited higher CO2 adsorption capacities compared to COF-OH, demonstrating that the incorporation of polypyridine nickel groups enhances the CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface. Qst were calculated from the CO2 adsorption isotherms using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation (Fig. 4(c)). The COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibited larger isosteric heats of adsorption (32.1 kJ·mol–1) compared to COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) (29.8 kJ·mol–1) and COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) (28.6 kJ·mol–1), indicating that the TPYNi(NO3 –) sites enhance binding affinities toward CO2, therefore improving CO2 adsorption abilities. Under 330 nm laser excitation, positive TA signals across the 380–620 nm range were observed for TPYNi, COF-OH, and their physical mixture, consistent with photoinduced absorption (PA) characteristics of electrons (Figs. 4(d), 4(e) and S27). As depicted in Fig. 5(a) , the peaks at 2343 and 2362 cm–1 correspond to the asymmetric stretching of CO2, indicating that the initial step in the catalytic process involves strong binding of CO2 to the COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) surface [ 61 ]. Notably, as the irradiation time increased, characteristic peaks for *COOH appeared at 1512 and 1107 cm–1, confirming *COOH as a key intermediate in the photoreduction process of CO2 to CO [ 65 ]. The ATR-SEIRAS results for COF-O-BPY(NO3 –) and COF-O-BPP(NO3 –) are consistent with those of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) as shown in Figs. S30 and S31. To gain deeper insights into the CO2 photoreduction mechanism over COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –), density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to elucidate the regulation of the electronic structure and catalytic performance. For the patical density of states (PDOS) of COF-OH, the valance band (VB) maximun is predominantly constituted by C-2p and O-2p states, while the conduction band (CB) minimun is primarily composed of C-2p and N-2p states (Figs. 5(b) and S32). Notably, significant electronic structure modifications were identified in COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –). Specifically, the PDOS analysis reveals that the CB minimun composition in COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) retains similarity to that of COF-OH, whereas the VB maximun is predominantly originates from Ni-3d and O-2p states within the TPYNi groups (Figs. 5(c) and S33). According to the total density of states (TDOS) profies, the incorporation of TPYNi(NO3 –) effectively generates new states proximal to the Fermi level and induces a pronounced shift of the CB minimum toward the Fermi level, suggesting enhanced photocatalytic activity for COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) compared to COF-OH (Fig. 5(d)). Consequently, the electrons in COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) can be more readily photoexcited to the conduction band, thereby facilitating their participation in the catalytic reaction. The formation energy of *COOH in COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) and COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) were 0.54 and 0.55 eV, respectively, indicating a minimal difference due to the coordination environment of the Ni center (Fig. 5(e)). In contrast, COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) exhibited a lower free energy barrier for *COOH generation (0.39 eV), which can be primarily attributed to the influence of the N atom in the pyrazole ring. However, the *CO desorption energy for COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –) was relatively high at 0.585 eV. Overall, the rate-determining step (RDS) for COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) and COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) is the formation of *COOH, while for COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –), the RDS is *CO desorption. The energy barriers of the RDS in COF-O-Ni samples follow the order: COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) < COF-O-BPYNi(NO3 –) < COF-O-BPPNi(NO3 –), which is consistent with the photocatalytic performance. Additionally, the calculated hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) free energy curves show that the ΔG values for *H formation on COF-O-Ni samples are significantly higher than the energy barriers for CO2 reduction, resulting in high selectivity for CO2 reduction to CO and effectively suppressing H2 production from water decomposition (Fig. S34). Furthermore, DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the energy barriers for CO2RR on COF-O-TPYNi with different coordinating anions (X = NO3 –, Cl–, and CH3COO–) (Fig. 5(f)). The formation free energy of the COOH* intermediate follows the order: COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) (0.543 eV) < COF-O-TPYNi(Cl–) (0.633 eV) < COF-O-TPYNi(CH3COO–) (0.681 eV), which is consistent with the observed experimental catalytic activity trends. A probable mechanism for CO2 photoreduction over COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) is proposed and illustrated in Fig. 5(g). Under visible light irradiation, [Ru(bpy)3]2+ is excited to form the excited {[Ru(bpy)3]2+}*. This species then accepts an electron from BIH, resulting in the formation of the reduced species [Ru(bpy)3]+. The reduced Ru(I) species subsequently injects electrons into the COF-OH skeleton, regenerating the ground-state [Ru(bpy)3]2+. The COF-OH acts as an efficient electron pump, facilitating charge separation and transferring electrons to the TPYNi active sites. The CO2 molecules adsorbed on the Ni sites accept electrons and protons to form a radical CO2 – intermediate, which further acquires a proton to produce *COOH intermediates. Subsequently, the *COOH intermediates accept another proton and electron to form *CO intermediates, which are eventually desorbed from the catalysts. The coordinating anions (eg. NO3 –, Cl–, and CH3COO–) can influence the electronic density of Ni active sites, leading to varying activation barriers for the rate-determining step of CO2 photoreduction. The results indicate that the ligands and coordinating anions significantly modulate the electronic structure of Ni(II) active sites, thereby reducing the CO2 activation barrier. Among them, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibits the lowest energy barrier. By enhancing charge transfer kinetics and lowering reaction barriers, the first or second coordination sphere (the ligands and coordinating anions) plays a crucial role in improving photocatalytic CO2RR performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed novel COF-O-Ni composite photocatalysts with high catalytic activity through a Williamson reaction. This approach not only retains the well-defined and highly tunable structural advantages of molecular catalysts but also extends visible light absorption, enhances charge separation, and facilitates recycling. Notably, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) exhibited significantly improved performance for photocatalytic CO2 reduction, with an efficiency of 9006.0 μmol·g–1·h–1 and selectivity of 95.9%, surpasses the performance of its counterpart catalysts. Experimental and theoretical analyses show that this performance improvement is attributed to the superior charge transfer characteristics and low *COOH energy barrier of COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –), which reduces the energy barrier and improves the overall efficiency. Our work provides a compelling example of modulating the coordination environment and electronic structure of composite catalysts to achieve efficient photocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: The coordination engineering of catalytic centers emerges as a pivotal strategy for precise electronic configuration modulation in photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Herein, the electronic structure of active sites in polypyridine nickel catalysts is well modified through strategic ligand variation (bipyridine, terpyridine (TPY), 2,6-di(1-pyrazolyl)pyridine) and anion coordination (NO3 –, Cl–, and CH3COO–), achieving enhanced CO2 performance. Crucially, covalent immobilization of these molecular catalysts within the COF-OH framework not only preserves their precisely defined and structurally adaptable characteristics but also demonstrates synergistic enhancement of CO2 adsorption capacity and charge transfer kinetics, as verified by CO2 adsorption isothermal analysis and ultrafast time-resolved transient absorption spectroscopy. Remarkably, COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) catalyst exhibits a CO2-to-CO reduction activity of 9006.0 μmol·g–1·h–1 with 95.9% selectivity, superior to its counterpart catalysts, directly validating the mechanistic significance of precisely tailored coordination microenvironments around Ni active sites. Mechanistic studies through in situ XAFS, in situ ATR-SEIRAS and theoretical calculations reveal that this performance improvement over COF-O-TPYNi(NO3 –) is attributed to the reduced reaction energy barrier of *COOH generation. This work pioneers a coordination shell engineering paradigm for rational design of molecularly defined catalytic architectures.
